nodes.text: A single-kernel, block-wise GPU error-bounded lossy compressor design (cuSZp) can achieve ultra-fast end-to-end throughput while maintaining high compression ratios and high reconstructed data quality for scientific HPC datasets
cuSZp implements compression and decompression entirely inside one GPU kernel using a block-wise pipeline to avoid CPU interactions and extra data movements

cuSZp pipeline consists of four major steps per block: (S1) pre-quantization and lightweight 1D 1-layer Lorenzo prediction, (S2) fixed-length encoding using per-block effective-bit detection and sign map, (S3) hierarchical global synchronization (exclusive prefix-sum) implemented with thread/warp/global levels, and (S4) block bit-shuffle to align bits into bytes

Design choices: use lightweight Lorenzo prediction (intra-block) to reduce bit entropy, use block fixed-length encoding instead of Huffman to trade some compression for much higher parallel throughput, and implement hierarchical prefix-sum to compute block offsets on GPU

Evaluation uses NVIDIA Ampere A100 GPU and six representative real-world HPC datasets (Hurricane, NYX, QMCPack, RTM, HACC, CESM-ATM) drawn from SDRBench; metrics include end-to-end throughput, kernel throughput, compression ratio, PSNR, SSIM, and visualization
Experimental evidence: comprehensive experiments on A100 with 6 datasets and multiple relative error bounds (REL 1E-1..1E-4) comparing cuSZp to cuSZ, cuSZx, and cuZFP
Putting all computations into one GPU kernel eliminates CPU computation and CPU-GPU memcpy overheads that dominate end-to-end runtime in prior GPU compressors (e.g., cuSZ, cuSZx)

Fixed-length per-block encoding plus bit-shuffle is more GPU-friendly and achieves high compression ratios on typical scientific data because blocks are spatially smooth (empirical CDFs show most blocks have small relative value ranges)

Quantization and prediction: pre-quantization maps floats to integers with guaranteed max absolute error within user error bound; Lorenzo prediction stores per-block differences li = ri - r_{i-1} to reduce effective bits

Fixed-length encoding: for each non-zero block compute max absolute quantized integer to determine per-block fixed bit-width F_k, store sign map, and compute compressed block size CmpL_k = (F_k + 1) * L / 8 (bytes)

Global synchronization: compute exclusive prefix-sum of per-block compressed sizes using hierarchical thread->warp->global scheme and chained-scan to produce start offsets for concatenation fully on GPU
Block bit-shuffle: reorganize bits across block elements into aligned bytes by bit-offset so writing variable-bit-width encoded data becomes regular and parallel-storeable
Evaluation measures end-to-end throughput from data resident in GPU memory to compressed bytes stored in GPU memory (so single-kernel implementations equate kernel and end-to-end throughput)

Throughput results: cuSZp achieves average end-to-end throughput 93.63 GB/s (compression) and 120.04 GB/s (decompression) on A100, which is 95.53x faster than cuSZ and 55.18x faster than cuSZx; kernel throughput of cuSZp is comparable to or higher than state-of-the-art single-kernel compressors

Compression ratio and data smoothness evidence: on 24 benchmark cases cuSZp attains the highest average compression ratio in 16 cases across tested error bounds; block smoothness analysis (CDFs) supports effectiveness of fixed-length block encoding

Reconstructed data quality: rate-distortion and visualization show cuSZp preserves higher PSNR and SSIM than cuZFP at comparable bit rates and removes artifacts produced by some block-constant or fixed-rate methods (evidenced on RTM, CESM-ATM, HACC, etc.)

Conclusion: cuSZp demonstrates that a carefully engineered single-kernel, block-wise GPU error-bounded compressor can deliver ultra-fast end-to-end throughput while achieving competitive or superior compression ratios and reconstructed data quality for diverse scientific datasets, making it suitable for inline GPU HPC simulations
